feed.title: First Page for DevSecOps training course
feed.subtitle: Example of page in Jekyll to cover the requisites of DevSecOps training course of Coursera.

entry.title: Ending
entry.content:
Creating Lists

You can create ordered and unordered lists in Markdown.

Unordered List

  • Item 1
  • Item 2
    • Subitem 2.1
    • Subitem 2.2
  • Item 3

Ordered List

  1. First item
  2. Second item
  3. Third item

Lists help organize information clearly!

entry.title: Making things
entry.content:
```markdown

layout: post title: “Using Tables in Jekyll” date: 2023-10-10 categories: jekyll markdown —

Adding Tables to Your Posts

You can create tables in Markdown like this:

Column 1 Column 2 Column 3
Row 1 Data 1 Data 2
Row 2 Data 3 Data 4
Row 3 Data 5 Data 6

Tables are great for organizing data!

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
Welcome to My HTML Post

This is an example of a Jekyll post written in HTML.

Why Use HTML?

HTML gives you more control over the structure and styling of your content.

  • Use <div> tags for layout.
  • Embed videos or iframes.
  • Add custom styles inline.

HTML is powerful and flexible!

entry.title: Interesting things
entry.content:
Custom Variables in Jekyll

You can use custom variables in your YAML front matter and reference them in your post.

Author Information

This post was written by **.

Custom Data

You can even add custom data like this:

  • Tags: jekyll, blogging, tutorials
  • Difficulty Level: Intermediate

Experiment with custom variables to make your posts more dynamic!

Method 1: Relative Path

entry.title: SE in on
entry.content:
Welcome to My First Post

This is an example of a basic Jekyll post written in Markdown.

Subheading

Here’s a list of things you can do with Jekyll:

  • Create blog posts.
  • Use Markdown for formatting.
  • Customize layouts and themes.

Code Example
